text: (light music)
- Welcome to "AWS for Data" on YouTube.
I'm Rousseau Dasgupta, and I lead
the UK B2B FinTech business here at AWS.

I'm really excited to be
welcoming two senior leaders

from one of our UK headquartered
fintechs today, Preqin.
Jack and James, if you could
quickly just introduce yourselves
and briefly what you do at Preqin.
- Sure, thanks, Rousseau, I'm Jack.
I head up platform,
manage all of our integrations
and our wider platform services.

- Hi, Rousseau, yeah, I'm a
VP of engineering at Preqin.

I work in the general
partners business unit
and the platform business unit with Jack.

- Wonderful, well, it's
wonderful to have you
here in the studio

and also may I compliment
you on your sock game
before we even get started.
- Thank you so much.
It's very similar to yours.
- It's a wonder why.

No, very good, so for
viewers who aren't familiar,

what are the business problems
that you solve at Preqin?
- Sure, well, at Preqin,

we essentially empower
financial professionals,

anyone who invests in or
allocates to alternatives.

We give them tools to make
confident investment decisions.
We've developed a wide range of solutions

really to support the entire
lifecycle of investments

and that raises from fundraising
to allocation decisions

to capital deployment
and portfolio monitoring.
And with our Preqin Anywhere solutions

which encompasses our APIs,
our feeds, our integrations,
and our third-party plugins,

we really try and make
it as easy to integrate
our data as possible.

- And what was the initial
vision of the company?
How's that evolved over time?

- Yeah, I mean we've been
in the business 20 years.
In fact, Preqin started in 2003
by Mark O'Hare and Nick Arnott
and was really built upon this ambition
to increase the transparency
of private markets through data.
They really came up

with this pioneering
approach for data collection
and it enabled them to build the first
or one of the foremost
private equity databases for performance.
First all, 20 years on,
we're now over 1,500 employees

and we support over 200,000
investment professionals.

We are 100% and remain 100%
focused on alternatives
and really make sure that we have

the most complete, comprehensive,
and in-depth dataset
across the key asset classes.

- Brilliant, and obviously
you've been in business
for over 20 years.

I mean, I'm sure a lot
has changed in that time.

How has AWS kind of gone
with you on that journey
and helped you to evolve and scale?
- So we migrated to the cloud in 2017
and what it's really enabled us to do
is scale to our customers

and also focus on really where
we're gonna provide value.

It's also changed the way that
we think and buy technology.

In terms of some of
the AWS-specific things

that have really helped
us change our business,
I think the Data Exchange

has really helped with our
feeds business and integrations.
- Yeah, absolutely.
- So Jack, James, I'd love to go
a bit deeper on kind of your data strategy
and I know listeners at home

will be thinking about
GenAI, a lot of these.
Everyone's talking about generative AI,
but I think what we've really seen
is from talking to our customers

that a lot of customers
just aren't even ready
for GenAI in production yet
and it's really given them a chance
to really look at the data foundations
they have in their companies,
looking at their overall data strategy,

the culture that they have
internally around data,

as well as the data
platforms that they build

that even enable use
cases like AI and GenAI.

So suppose where I'd love
to start is to think about

what role does data play in
Preqin's strategy as a company?
- Well, I guess, data is in our DNA,

so we really believe that
a successful data strategy,

it's got to align to
what our customers need
and expect from us.
And to that end,

we've really tried to
bring our data organization

and our product organization
closer together,
and we've built out cross-functional teams

that align to the type of
customer types we have.

Look, it goes without saying
that for a business like ours,
the focus on data quality is absolute.

We can build the best
software tools in the world,
the best integrations, the best APIs.
But if the data isn't right,
none of that really matters.
So to ensure that,

we've continually invested
in people, process
and technology to make sure
that we can really do this at scale.
- Great, and that last point you mentioned
that people, process, technology,
I mean, that's really, really important.

It's what we've really
seen is kind of unlocking

a lot of these benefits
for a lot of our customers.
What I'd really love to know
is can you share any key insights

or changes internally that
you've had from doing that
and that have been driven by data
internally in your company?

- Sure, maybe James,
you can speak to that.

- Yeah, I mean, one of
the big things we did is,

as Jack mentioned, we're bringing
various elements together

and one of the biggest changes
was bringing product analysts
into our cross-functional teams.

That really gave us the
ability to start looking
at what our customers were doing

in a way that gave us that
extra edge of professionalism
and it also gave us the ability

to identify high value
actions for our customers

and then start thinking
about ways to get them

to move them to that value
faster and more efficiently,

and overall providing a
better user experience
and customer experience too.

- That's really, really
interesting to hear

and I think what's really
unique about you as a company,

and maybe it's a little bit
different from what viewers

may have seen on some
of our other interviews,
is that you're not only talking
about your own data strategy,
but you also monetize your data

and sell it to customers
as your main product.

So I'd really love to
talk a little bit more

about how you shape your
customer's data strategies as well.
So first I'd like to know
what kind of product choices have you made

to better support your
customer's data strategy?

- Sure, I mean, I'd say
something I've noticed,
especially over the last five years,
is that our customers
and their appetite for technology
is increasing in sophistication.
Now more than ever,

I think they see the
value of seeing our data

tightly integrated into
their own ecosystems.
Like a lot of companies in our fields,

we started out with data
feeds, built out APIs.

But what's become really clear
to us is to do this at scale,

we have to lower the
barrier to our adoption
or to coin an Amazon term,
meet our customers where they are.
So to that end,
we're looking at what sort of tools

and services we can
build on top of our APIs.
As James mentioned just previously,

the AWS Data Exchange
has been a great exemplar
of this for us
and based on customer feedback,

we've also gone further to
build out direct integrations
to some of the most widely-used ARM tools,
as well as BI analytics tools too.
- No, that's amazing, and it's really good
to hear about that.

One thing I also wanted
to dive a bit deeper on

is that are there any key
customer roadmap items
that you've kind of implemented
to keep up with the data requirements

that customers have as
they change over time?
- Yeah, I mean, absolutely.

It's front and center
for a company like us.
Without giving away too many secrets,
some of the big ticket items

we're looking to tackle
this year are around search.
You mentioned GenAI earlier
and that may not be the technology we use,

but I think the spirit of
helping our customers get to data

and get to value quicker
is absolutely something
we're gonna lean into this year.
So really kind of improving that ability
to also map our data.

We are hyper aware that we
don't exist in our silo.

We're one of many providers
for a number of our customers,

so how can we make it
ever more easy for them

to map our data into A, their
existing proprietary data
and also other third-party data providers
that they're taking data from?

We're also building out a
suite of internal tools.
As we mentioned earlier,

data quality at scale is
absolutely fundamental for us,

so we are making some investment
into our internal tooling
and people and processes
to make sure we can continue to do this.
At this point, it'd be remiss
not to touch on AI and ML technologies.

We're increasingly looking
at ways that we can use these

to free up our talented
data and research colleagues

so that they're not focusing
time on menial tasks
and really are doing high value actions
that make sure we're delivering
the best possible data for our customers,

and we see that as a key
part of doing this at scale.

- Yeah, no, I think that
makes a lot of sense
and it's a common pattern that we see
actually widely in the industry,

that a big part of the impact
of different kind of AI

and machine-learning
technologies is that augmentation
of kind of existing resource,

allowing people to focus
on more customer value
which obviously we all love.
So Jack or James,

I mean, would you be able to
maybe share with us an example
of how those kind of data
and insights have shaped the direction
of an existing kind of feature

or project that you've
already been working on
and perhaps changed how that turned up?

- Yeah, absolutely, so
we kind of really leaned

into analytics in a big
way about four years ago

and as we started to map user
journeys through our platform,
one thing that jumped out of at us
was the vast majority of them
seemed to end in a download action,

and that was kind of a
strong indication to us

that people were taking
our data off a platform
to take actions with it.
So we saw that as a trigger.
We spoke to a number of customers
and really wanted to understand the why?
Why were they doing this?

What were the problems
they were trying to solve?

And what became clear was there
was this absolute appetite
to consume data in their own ecosystems,
their own systems and workflows,
and that was really the trigger for us

to invest into our Preqin
Anywhere initiative.

So we started to build
out data feeds and APIs

and what came out was that
customers really wanted
to see this in a number of ways.
Quite often in their CRM systems,
but also increasingly into data warehouses
and to drive analytics.
It really served as a trigger for us
then to kind of invest in this
and crucially solve that customer problem

of not having busy
investment professionals
manually moving data around,

but letting technology
do the heavy lifting
and again, freeing them up to do
the more valuable actions in their day.
- No, brilliant, so recurring theme there

around getting to customer
value a bit faster

and it's very aligned
with the kinds of things

that we try to help a
lot of our customers do.

So I suppose a kind of a
natural question from there
is as you've gone through this journey,

this transformation of
bringing in more data insights,
analytics into the way
that you prioritize your product roadmap
and what you do with your customers,

are there any of those
areas where I guess AWS
has been a catalyst

or something that's helped
you along that journey?

- I think AWS has really
aided that journey.

Going back to what we
said before about scaling,
and flexibility, and what we focus on,
a lot of the commoditized services

are really helpful in
getting towards these goals
we find our users need.

So I think search on
platform is one example

where we've gone with an AWS
service around OpenSearch

and that's really
enabled us to leverage it

without having to really
operate at a level of detail

that means we have to hire that
expertise and other things.

The kind of things you
would usually expect
from using cloud providers.

- That's a really interesting
example there, James,

and I suppose one thing we
haven't really talked about yet

is as you kind of increase
your organization's ability
to make these kind of decisions,
there's a kind of prerequisite there
that you kind of have to have
a bit of a data-driven culture,

that your people have to
think along the right lines

to be able to make
those kind of decisions.

So I suppose I'd love to
know how do you foster
data literacy within your teams at Preqin?

- Yeah, absolutely, I
mean, it's been a journey,

but I'd say probably the
main way we've done that

is to bring our products and
data teams closer together
and really put data at the heart
of our products and engineering process.

One practical way we've done
this is to embed analysts

and data scientists right
into the heart of those teams.
A major cultural shift I think we've made
has been to focus on product outcomes
that are measurable too

and avoid the trap of
becoming a feature factory,

as it's all too easy to
do when building product.

What we've really done
is incentivize people
to become data literate

and ultimately more
customer-centric as part of that.

I'd say like more broadly
though as a company,
we've tried to kind of build this in
right on the onboarding process.
So when somebody joins Preqin,

they'll go through a fairly
kind of intensive process
of learning about our customers, our data,
and the broader alternatives market
and ultimately that will put data
at the heart of what they're doing
'cause they're doing it from day one.
- I'd love it if you could maybe speak
to some of the challenges that you've had

building that data-centric
culture within Preqin
and how did you go about
kind of overcoming those challenges?

- So of course, there
have been challenges.
I mean, every business as you say
is gonna face some challenges
when making a cultural shift of any sort.
But I think the challenges for Preqin

around this datacentricity
have been mainly to do
with the way we've reorganized

in the last few years
around business units

and this cross-functional
teams that we mentioned.
We've had challenges naturally from that
around communication and other things

and I think we've had to
really make sure that data,

in the way that we are
talking about it now,
is included in that transition.
- No, very good, very good to hear.
So I'd like to shift gears for a moment
and maybe talk a little bit about tooling.
There's been a real Cambrian explosion
of kind of different tools and platforms
and everything promising more scalability,

more ability to take on
huge volumes of data,

the ability to create more
and more accurate models
and things like that.

But one thing that we've often
thought about here at AWS

is advising customers
to use that right tool
for the right job.
And I suppose with that in mind,
how do you make technology decisions

internally that help you
actually support your strategy?

- So we actually have a
governance process for that
which makes it sound quite restrictive,
but actually anyone can instigate that,
and I think that gives us the ability
to include a diversity of opinions
and anyone in the business

can really interact with that
too 'cause it's accessible.
It's not just about technology.

It's about the outcomes
we're searching for.
And also I think we'll talk to AWS, right?
We'll talk to our technology partners,
anyone that we're interacting with
on that level to get advice,

and I think that's very
valuable a lot of the time.
- Yeah, that's very good to know,

and I suppose how do you
then strike that balance?
There's always new things coming out,

new frameworks, new
tools, new methodologies.
How do you strike that balance
between experimenting with shiny new tools

and using a tried and tested
and true existing methods
that you already have?

- So I think that boils
down to the balance

is really between innovation
and stability, right?
I think that you can fall foul
of just jumping on the next trend
and it comes back to bite you

or there's some aspect of it
that wasn't quite a good fit.

So we actually have an
innovation account that,
well, it's another AWS account
that we call the innovation account

and that's a place for us to
explore these technologies
and implement stuff in there.
And in terms of our customer interaction,
we actually have beta testing
and A/B testing as well
which can help us as well make sure
that things like performance
and other aspects are gonna provide
that value for our customer.

- Oh, brilliant, so I
suppose on the subject
of shiny tools and new techniques
and things like that,

what are you doing at the
moment with generative AI?
We touched on this before,
but it'd be good to get an idea
of kind of where you're at with that
and how you're thinking about it.

- I think like any company
that has a technology function,
we're looking into generative AI
and we're obviously experimenting
with it in various contexts.
And I think, Jack,

you've got something to
say about that as well.
- Yeah, I mean, I think it's great
and we'll stay close to it
like pretty much everyone in our field.
What I try and focus on though

is not to get distracted
by the technology too much
and make sure we're staying laser focused
on the problems we're trying to solve.
And if GenAI is the answer, then great,

but there may be other
easier ways to do that.
So we wanna stay responsible,
we wanna stay cautious,

but obviously kind of trying
to leverage this technology
where it makes sense for us.

- Yeah, we wanna stay
focused on the outcomes
for our customers, yeah.
- Yeah, no, definitely, and I think we've,

again, we've seen that a lot
with a lot of our customers,

that they start with kind
of lower hanging fruit,

things that are a bit less
controversial, a bit easier.
They don't require as much perhaps thought
on the privacy, security,
and the ethics frankly a lot of the time.
So no, it's good to hear that.

Now GenAI is just one catalyst
for our industry as a whole.

I mean, things are moving
really, really fast.

I think things are evolving
faster than we've ever seen
in the software industry
and in financial services as as well.
I guess as these disruptions play out,

how do you kind of envision
the future of the industry
and how data might shape that?
- I think in the industry,

there's more data collection
happening than ever before
and I think there's a growing appetite

to adopt technologies to
make sense of that data
and also scale your business

to cope with the increased
demand that comes from that.
- But I think the challenge of more data
is how to make sense of it, right?
So the challenge to us
and companies like us

is to really distill that
into those valuable insights.
And to that end,
we're trying to lean into personalization

and try and understand the
jobs that our customers do

and serve those relevant
insights at the right time

so they're deriving as much
value as quickly as possible.

- I love it just-in-time data
for just the right decision.
That's a really exciting future for sure.
I suppose as you look forward to it,

how are you thinking about
your company's data strategy

evolving to try and help
customers with that?
- Yeah, I mean, I guess the starting point

is to make sure that we
continue to maximize value.

We're fortunate to be part of
a rapidly expanding market.
To the end of 2023,
global alternative asset under management,
around $16 trillion.

By 2028, we predict that to be
in excess of $24.5 trillion,
so lots to play for there.
I think the challenge is therefore for us

to make sure that we
continue to collect data
and deliver it on quality

and deliver it to customers
in the way, and the manner,

and the channel that makes
the most sense to them,

and ultimately make sure that
we continue on our mission
to bring as much transparency
to private markets as possible.

- I wanna thank you both for
the time you've given us today.
But just in terms of one final question,
I'd love to ask you to kind of leave
the audience with something,
something tangible, something actionable.
I suppose for businesses
starting out right now on this journey,

what advice would you give
them in getting started
in creating a data strategy, data culture,

data platform to serve
their company going forward?
- I think for any business starting out,
it's important to identify what value
you're providing to the customer
and work backwards from there.
And then from that basis,

you can decide what
the essential tools are
you need to provide that

and then you should look to
leverage commoditized services
and things like cloud providers like AWS

so that you don't have to
spend an awful lot of time

and energy figuring
out the nuts and bolts.
You can move straightforward
and get to that value sooner.

I would also say that
it's important to embed
the importance of data in your culture

and your values of the
business from the beginning.

I think there's a lot
of missed opportunities

with collecting the right
data, particularly in startups,

and I think that embedding
that in the values

and culture can really
alleviate that problem.
- Well, thanks both for coming in today.

It's been really fascinating
to talk about your journey

creating this kind of
amazing culture of data

and this data strategy
that you have at Preqin.
I suppose if our viewers wanna find out
a bit more about you,
where can they go?

Where can they find out more
information about Preqin?
- Yeah, absolutely, we'd encourage you
to follow us on LinkedIn
and also go onto our website, preqin.com.
Check out the PressHub
and find out much more about us.
We'd love you to do that.

- Jack, James, thanks so
much for the time today
and to our viewers at home,
thanks very much for tuning in.
This is "AWS for Data."
